description:
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) genotype 3 is a genetic variant of the Hepatitis C virus, which is a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Hepacivirus genus within the Flaviviridae family. Genotype 3 is one of the six major genotypes of HCV identified globally, characterized by distinct genetic sequences and distribution patterns.

HCV genotype 3 is known to have a higher prevalence in certain regions, such as South Asia, and is associated with a higher risk of developing liver steatosis (fatty liver) and more rapid progression to liver cirrhosis compared to other HCV genotypes. This genotype is also considered more challenging to treat with some older direct-acting antiviral (DAA) therapies, although newer treatment options have improved outcomes for individuals infected with HCV genotype 3.

Understanding the specific characteristics of HCV genotype 3 is important for clinical management, as it can inform decisions regarding treatment regimens and monitoring of disease progression in infected individuals.
